title: Week Ahead: Attack On Saudi Oil Output Will Drive Wild Ride For Markets
text:
Saturday's attack on Saudi oil facilities reshuffles next week's market expectations

All U.S indices posted third weekly gain at Friday's close

Treasury yields climb for an 8th day to a six-week high

Just when it appeared the stars were aligning for equity market bulls, with U.S. economic data improving, global monetary policy easing and hopes for a trade resolution looking more likely, a on a critical Saudi Aramco processing installation, Saturday, set the facility and the Kingdom's second largest oil field ablaze, halting production in those locations.

What should have been a quiet upcoming week, as equities paused at record high prices ahead of Wednesday's crucial and the central bank's much anticipated , is set to become, instead, a wild ride with markets—and governments—on high alert for possible military escalation in the Middle East.

New Tone For Next Week's Markets

U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo blamed Iran for the attack on the “world’s energy supply,” which was carried out by Houthi rebels based in Yemen, who are allied with Iran. The strike damaged half of the Desert Kingdom’s production, which amounts to 5% of the global oil supply.

Pompeo accused Iran of pretending “to engage in diplomacy” while calling "for de-escalation.” In a tweet he said Iran will be "held accountable for its aggression."

This weekend's events have set a new tone for next week's markets, even after all four U.S. indices—the , , and —climbed for a third straight week. Expect extreme amid marked sector rotation.

As well, will likely jump at the start of commodity market trade tomorrow, possibly by as much as $10 while other risk sectors may plummet.

WTI Weekly

Even if the price of oil opens as much as $10 higher, it will still be below the $66.60 April high, whose peak must be bested to establish a medium-term uptrend.

The S&P 500 slipped on Friday (-0.07%), with leading the laggards, (-1.2%). led the green sectors, (+1.13%).

JPM Daily

also gained, (+0.83%). Global banks, including JPMorgan Chase (NYSE: ) (+1.97% on Friday, +6.77% for the week), rode the Treasury's yield jump to a record high for the bank's shares. The stock completed a H&S continuation pattern, suggesting further gains ahead.

The sector (-0.72%) slumped, however, pressured by Apple (NASDAQ: ), (-1.94%), and Broadcom (NASDAQ: ), (-3.41%), after on Thursday, during its Q3 2019 , that demand remains weak.

The SPX advanced 0.96% on a weekly basis, with 8 of the 11 sectors in the green, led by Financials (+3.83%), (+3.47%) and Materials (+3.32%). Yields on the U.S. 10-year Treasury note climbed for an 8th day to finish the week, hitting a six-week high. Technically, rates crossed above the downtrend line since May 3 and are now aiming for the downtrend line since Nov. 7.

USD/JPY Daily

The pair ended lower on Friday, for the first time in five days, for the second time in nine days, after the failed to best the 100 DMA, to close at the very top of a falling channel.

posted the biggest weekly gain against the dollar since May, as well as its longest run of weekly gains since 2016 versus the , after the Times reported possible progress in Brexit negotiations related to the contentious Irish backstop. Prime Minister Boris Johnson will meet EU President Jean-Claude Juncker next week.

EUR/GBP Daily

Technically, the completed a descending peak-trough series, establishing a downtrend, while the 200 DMA provided support on Friday.

XAU/USD Daily

has fallen to less than 0.1% from its lowest since Aug. 6. Technically, it found support at the bottom of a rising channel since late May, while both the RSI and the MACD provided sell signals.

Week Ahead

All times listed are EDT

5:00: Eurozone – : likely to have remained flat at 1.0% YoY during August while jumping to 0.2% from -0.5% .

8:30: U.S. – : probably slipped to 1.300M from 1.317M.

8:30: Canada – : was 0.3% in the previous read.

10:30: U.S. – : previous read was -6.912M barrels.

14:00: U.S. – : investors expect the Fed to trim its fund target rate range by 25 basis points this week.

Thursday

8:30: U.S. – : expected to plunge to 11.0 from 16.8.

Friday

8:30: Canada – : seen to drop to 0.4% from 0.9% for the month of July.
description: Market Overview Analysis by Pinchas Cohen/Investing.com covering: GBP/USD, USD/JPY, EUR/GBP, XAU/USD. Read Pinchas Cohen/Investing.com's latest article on Investing.com
